#Text=Maktul Hacı Ibrahim
#Text=Pasha
#Text=This article is about the governor of Egypt in 1604 .
#Text=For the earlier governor of Egypt named Ibrahim Pasha , also known by the epithet Maktul ( " the Slain " ) , see Pargalı Ibrahim Pasha .
#Text=For other people , see Ibrahim Pasha ( disambiguation ) .
#Text=In this Ottoman Turkish style name , Ibrahim is the given name , the title is Pasha , and there is no family name .
#Text=Ibrahim Pasha ( also known as Hacı Ibrahim Pasha or Maktul Ibrahim Pasha or among his Arab subjects as Ibrahim Pasha al-Maqtul , [ 1 ]

#Text=Maktul meaning the Slain ; died 24 September 1604 [ 2 ] ) was an Ottoman statesman who served shortly as the governor of Egypt in 1604 before he was murdered by mutinying sepahi soldiers of the Ottoman Army .
#Text=He also served as defterdar ( finance minister ) of the Ottoman Empire four times ( 1582 – 83 , 1587 – 88 , 1593 – 94 , 1596 ) .
#Text=Background
#Text=Ibrahim Pasha appears to have lived in Konya in his early life and been a dervish and a follower of the ascetic Muslim mystic Rumi . [ 3 ]
#Text=As such , he was sometimes known by the epithet " Sufi " by historians . [ 3 ]
#Text=He was also a kadı ( judge ) at some point in his life prior to becoming the four-time defterdar of the empire and governor of Egypt . [ 4 ]
#Text=Tenure as the governor of Egypt
#Text=In 1604 , sultan Ahmed I appointed Ibrahim Pasha as the governor of Egypt , Egypt then being the seat of the Egypt Eyalet of the Ottoman Empire .
#Text=His office 's title was beylerbey , while governors of a province in general was referred to as a wāli .

#Text=Since the Ottoman conquest of Egypt and their subjugation in 1517 , Mamluks in Egypt had been silently pushing for more influence in Egypt ; they often attempted this by trying to influence the garrisoned Ottoman soldiers over the Ottoman governor . [ 2 ]

#Text=After Ibrahim Pasha was appointed governor in 1604 , he began to enforce more stringent rules for the soldiers , especially those from the sipahi corps ( an elite cavalry corps of the Ottoman Army ) , [ 2 ] putting some of them to death . [ 5 ]

#Text=Allegedly , Ibrahim Pasha had one such soldier from the fellah ( Arabic-speaking ) class of the local Mamluk populace put to death by hanging and had his body draped in a sirwal ( Arabic baggy trousers ) , which was something both the local sepahis and the Mamluks wore , in order to send a message of his distaste for both groups ; furthermore , the body was then allegedly placed in a jar to symbolize the slave class the two groups belonged to . [ 5 ]
#Text=Another source states that tensions rose when Ibrahim Pasha refused to pay a briberous " accession tax " to the local sepahis for coming into the office of the governor of Egypt . [ 6 ]
#Text=Sipahis , in further corruption , self-enacted an illegal tax known as the tulba on the people of the Egyptian countryside , claiming that the tax was for " facilitating police duties .

#Text=After murdering the pasha , the rebel soldiers displayed his and some of his men 's heads publicly , parading them through the streets and then placing them on the gate of Bab Zuweila , where criminals ' remains were normally displayed , allegedly crying , " This is due to [ deserved by ] those who cause strife in the Sultan 's army .

#Text=Legacy
34-1	4480-4486	Legacy	abstract	new	_	_

#Text=Ibrahim Pasha 's death caused a period of instability and distress in Egypt , and stability was only restored around 7 or 8 years later when the governor Kara Mehmed Pasha finally crushed the rebellion , earning his epithet Kul Kıran (  the Slavebreaker " ) . [ 2 ]
